III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on central registry
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and suitable
Description and able to meet the needs of children and families served by the
agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster care case manager made inappropriate comments about
foster parents to foster youth during case contacts.
Investigation On 3/10/25 DCWL received an email dated 3/7/25 that Foster
Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 sent to Licensing Supervisor and
Foster Care Supervisor. The email reported concerns regarding
the previous and current foster care case workers, Foster Care
Worker 1 and Foster Care Worker 2. The concerns were as
follows:
• Children reported that workers have been visiting them at
school and making inappropriate remarks to intentionally
undermine foster parents.
• Workers told the children, “What happens in Vegas, stays
in Vegas” encouraging children to withhold information from
foster parents and parents.
• While transporting children, the worker was on the phone
speaking negatively about foster parents.
• Worker made inappropriate remarks to children, claiming
foster parents are “only in this for the money” and
discussing how much money caregivers received.
• Agency leadership was informed of these incidents, but
there has not been any resolution.
Interviews
Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 were jointly interviewed by
phone on 3/13/25. Regarding the items outlined in the allegations,
Foster Parent 1 reported Licensing Supervisor, Foster Care
Supervisor, and Section Manager were made aware of their
concerns. Foster Parent 1 stated they felt like their concerns were
not addressed, as Foster Care Worker 2 (FCW2) continues to
“nitpick” their actions and say things that should not be said in
front of the foster children about the money that is paid for their
care. Foster Parent 1 stated that Foster Care Worker 1 (FCW1)
also spoke with the children about money that was paid for their
2

care. One of the children reported that FCW1 said, “they wouldn’t
have that f***ing house without foster care payments”. This was
reportedly said in front of a Youth C. Foster Parent 1 stated they
pride themselves on doing a lot of fun activities with kids in their
care. More than what foster care payments would cover. Foster
Parent 1 added that FCW1 told the kids previously that the foster
parents did not care about them, and the kids were just a
paycheck.
Foster Parent 1 reported FCW2 visited Youth A at school and
informed the youth they were moving to Independent Living and
did not have a choice in the matter. FCW2 reportedly told Youth A
it was out of their control and came from the “higher ups”. Youth
A then told his parent that Foster Parent 1 put in a notice to have
him moved. Youth A and his parent were very upset by this.
Foster Parent 1 stated FCW2 also went to the school recently and
bad mouthed them to Youth A, then said, “what happens in
Vegas, stays in Vegas.” Foster Parent 2 expressed frustration
about FCW2 visiting the children at school. Foster Parent 1 stated
they understand that FCW2 can visit the children at school without
informing the caregiver, but the negative comments to the youth
were an issue.
Foster Parent 1 reported they did put in a notice for removal of
Youth C, as they were planning to go to Independent Living
anyway, and they were always suspended from school. FCW2
said Youth C would be leaving, but it did not happen quickly.
Foster Parent 1 reported they typically took youth as a ‘last resort’.
The kids they accepted had high Determination of Care (DOC)
rates. Foster Parent 1 expressed frustration that after the youth
were in their home for a while and behaviors improved, the DOC
rate was decreased. Foster Parent 1 described it as feeling like a
pay cut for doing good work with the kids. DCWL Consultant
explained to Foster Parent 1 that DOC rates were based on the
level of extra care or activities the foster parent was required to
do, to address a youth’s needs. If behaviors improved and
required less intervention or transportation to appointments
decreased, then the rate may decrease. Foster Parent 1 indicated
they understood.
Foster Parent 1 reported Youth C indicated they were in the car
and heard FCW2 speaking negatively on the phone with Foster
Care Supervisor about the foster parents. Youth C also reported
FCW2 showed them emails that indicated the amount paid to
caregivers. Foster Parent 1 felt it was inappropriate for the worker
to share that information with the youth.
3

Foster Parent 1 stated they planned to take Youth A, Youth B and
Youth C on a trip out of the country. FCW2 said the kids could go.
Foster Parent 1 purchased tickets, air fare, and told the kids. The
kids were very excited. Then the next day, FCW2 told them they
could not go, because the Chief Administrator said the trip was not
appropriate. FCW2 told Foster Parent 1 they should not be
spending that much money on the kids, as it was not appropriate.
Foster Parent 1 stated they did not contact the Chief Administrator
or file a grievance regarding their concerns. Foster Parent 1
expressed fear of retaliation by the agency. Foster Parent 1 was
told by Youth C that FCW2 said, “they are making too much
money in that house. They won’t make that much when I’m done
with them.” Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 verified they had
not heard any of the statements about money from FCW1 or
FCW2, nor did they have any of these statements in text or email.
This information was provided to them verbally by foster youth that
reported hearing the statements from FCW1 and FCW2.
Follow-up email contact occurred with Foster Parent 1 on 4/3/25,
in which they reported feeling targeted. Foster Parent 1 stated
they felt the agency was going to retaliate against them and cause
a special evaluation to be opened. Foster Parent 1 stated the
agency had previously taken information and turned it on them, to
start a special evaluation. Foster Parent 1 did not provide further
detail. Foster Parent 1 indicated they believed their special
evaluations were only valid for a year or two and should no longer
be used against them. DCWL Consultant responded that if Foster
Parent 1 felt targeted, they should contact the Chief Administrator
and file a grievance. Foster Parent 1 was also informed that
special evaluations never expire and can be used for assessment
of a foster home for the duration of their licensure. In addition, the
agency is required to open a special evaluation any time they
receive information of a potential rule violation. Regardless of if
they believe it to be true or not. The agency does not have the
option to receive information, then determine a special evaluation
was not needed.
Chief Administrator was contacted by email on 3/11/25. Chief
Administrator was informed of the allegation. Chief Administrator
provided names and contact information for staff involved. Email
contact occurred again on 4/3/25 to notify Chief Administrator of
the family’s concerns and interest in information regarding a
grievance. On 5/5/25 follow-up occurred via email. Chief
Administrator reported he would reach out to Foster Parent 1 and
Foster Parent 2 to discuss concerns and how to file a grievance if
they chose to do so.
4

Foster Care Worker 1 (FCW1) was interviewed via video call on
3/20/25. FCW1 reported she was transferred from Youth C’s case
due to Foster Parent 1 feeling that she purposely denied DOC
levels. FCW1 stated that she never spoke negatively about foster
parents in front of the children in the home, nor did she ever have
inappropriate conversations with the children. The only time
Foster Parent 1 was mentioned to Youth C was during a
discussion about clothing allowances. Youth C asked for the
money for clothing, and FCW1 redirected Youth C to Foster
Parent 1, as they had received the money. FCW1 denied ever
telling youth that the foster parents did not care about them or only
fostered for the money.
FCW1 stated the foster parents did not transport kids to visits or
therapy, which affected their DOC rate. Foster Parent 1 reportedly
was upset by this, as they believed transportation was the
worker’s responsibility. During the case, Foster Parent 1 put in a
30-day replacement request, with the denied DOC rate attached.
FCW1 explained the original DOC rate at placement was higher,
as the placement was an emergency. After Youth C was in the
home and reassessed, it was determined they did not meet the
requirements for a higher rate. One of the factors was that the
foster parents were not willing to assist with transportation, which
affected the DOC score. Foster Parent 1 stated they would ask for
removal if the rate was denied. A Team Decision Meeting (TDM)
occurred to discuss what could be done to maintain the
placement. Foster Parent 1 stated they would only consider
rescinding the notice if the rate was approved. A few days later,
Youth C became upset with FCW1, yelling and screaming in the
car that it was the worker’s fault they had to move. FCW1
explained to Youth C that it was not anyone’s fault as the plan was
always for them to go to Independent Living. FCW1 denied ever
speaking about the DOC rate or money with Youth C or showing
them documentation about foster care rates. FCW1 stated she
never heard any staff speak negatively about the foster parents in
front of the children placed in the home. However, it was known
that the foster parents would only take placement of youth with
high DOC levels, which some people may interpret in a certain
way. FCW1 was under the impression that Foster Parent 1 did
not have any concerns about FCW2, as to their knowledge none
had been reported until now.
Foster Care Worker 2 (FCW2) was interviewed via video call on
3/17/25. FCW2 reported Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2
never directly told her of any of their concerns. FCW2 stated they
5

never spoke with any youth about the foster parents or their
finances. FCW2 never heard any other staff talk about the foster
parents or their finances. Staff noticed the foster parents would
only accept placement of youth with high DOC rates. This was
evident in a recent removal request for Youth C, in which there
was a meeting that Foster Parent 1 stated they would only
maintain placement of Youth C if the high DOC level was
approved. FCW2 stated DOC levels were also a factor with Youth
A, as he was initially placed at a $300 per day rate due to it being
an emergency. At the 30-day reassessment, the rate renewal was
denied by central office. A request for $200 per day and $150 per
day were also submitted and denied. FCW2 stated that she
appropriately scored Youth A on the DOC at a level 2, which
Foster Parent 1 was unhappy about. However, the DOC rate was
never discussed with, or in front of, the youth. FCW2 stated one
reason the higher DOC level was not approved was because the
foster parents would not transport the youth to medical/dental
appointments, counseling, and parenting time. The other reason
for the lower score was due to Youth A not having any behavioral
issues as initially reported. Regarding Youth C’s DOC rate, it
lowered for the same reason. The foster parents were not
transporting youth to medical/dental appointments, visits, and
therapy. It was also reported Youth C did not have therapy
scheduled for the last few weeks. In addition, FCW2 reported that
the foster parents had not been available to the school and would
not respond to calls from the school when Youth C was in trouble
or needed to be picked up. FCW2 noted the foster parents
recently began transporting Youth C from parenting time once per
week, which would be included in the next reevaluation.
FCW2 again denied ever speaking negatively to any of the youth
about the foster parents or their finances. Recently Youth C
inquired about their clothing allowance. FCW2 redirected Youth C
to Foster Parent 1, as they had received the money for clothing.
This occurred with Foster Care Supervisor present.
FCW2 stated the agency had a few meetings with the foster
parents over the past month or two regarding the group home
license denial and the trip out of the country. FCW2 stated the
foster parents told the youth about the trip before receiving
MDHHS approval. The youth had already informed their parents
about it, before MDHHS was informed. FCW2 stated she was told
about the trip, but did not approve it, as she knew it needed
approval at a level above her. Ultimately the administration
decided the trip could not be approved, which the youth and foster
parents were upset about. FCW2 did not believe the youth would
make up allegations about staff as a result of being upset about
6

not going on the trip. However, she noted Youth B said he felt it
was FCW2’s fault they could not go. Youth C’s mother also called
FCW2, yelling that it was her fault the youth could not go. FCW2
and FC Supervisor spoke with the kids to explain why the decision
was made. FCW2 denied making any threats of retaliation toward
Foster Parents or stating, “they won’t make that much when I’m
done with them”.
Licensing Supervisor was interviewed via video call on 3/14/25.
Licensing Supervisor reported there was recently a TDM as the
foster parents wanted to take Youth A, Youth B and Youth C on a
trip out of the country. The team discussed the need for parental
consent, passports, etc. Licensing Supervisor stated the foster
parents were not specifically told the kids could go on the trip, as
they remembered FCW2 stating that Section Manager and Chief
Administrator would have the final say. After the upper
management decided the kids could not go on the trip, the foster
parents were informed via email. Foster Parent 1 was upset and
contacted Licensing Supervisor to report concerns about FCW2.
Foster Parent 1 had not brought any concerns about FCW2 to
their attention prior to that. Licensing Supervisor reported she
never heard any concerns about FCW2 from anyone else. When
asked about any history with the foster parents, Licensing
Supervisor indicated their license had been transferred to their
office in 2022. They had approximately eight special evaluations
previously. The foster parents recently applied for a group home
license, but it was denied due to the number of special
evaluations. Licensing Supervisor stated she never heard any
staff indicate that the family fostered for the money, or any
statements about their financial status.
Section Manager was interviewed via video call on 3/14/25.
Section Manager reported the foster parent’s concerns were
discussed with them previously regarding FCW1. A meeting
occurred and ultimately the agency decided to change the
assigned case worker as it seemed to be the only resolution the
foster parents were satisfied with. FCW2 was then assigned to the
children in the home. Recently, Foster Parent 1 reported similar
concerns about FCW2. A plan was developed to have Foster Care
Supervisor present for any home visits, and to be present by
phone during any transportation of youth. This plan was
developed in order to have a third-party present to verify what was
or was not occurring. Section Manager reported there were no
prior performance concerns regarding FCW1 or FCW2.
Section Manager stated they planned to schedule a meeting to
discuss the concerns from the 3/7/25 email, with the foster
7

parents. However, the foster parents did not respond to Section
Manager’s offer of three dates/times for a meeting to occur.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed via video call on
3/14/25. FCS was aware of the prior concerns reported about
FCW1. FCS reported she did not hear FCW1 make any
inappropriate remarks about the foster parents. After the foster
parents reported they were uncomfortable with FCW1, the agency
changed the children’s worker to FCW2. FCS reported that she
was never informed of any concerns about FCW2, until the email
on 3/7/25 that initiated this investigation. FCS never heard FCW2
say anything inappropriate about Foster Parent 1 or Foster Parent
2. FCS stated she had frequent communication with FCW2 when
she was out on visits. However, FCS always checked with FCW2
to ensure no one was present when they were having a phone
conversation. FCS denied participating in a call with FCW2, with
Youth C in the car, where they discussed the foster parents or
finances. FCS stated FCW2 is a very good worker and has been
with the agency for a long time, without any prior performance
issues. FCS said she could not imagine FCW2 speaking
inappropriately about any caregivers or parents. When the
complaint was reported, FCS and FCW2 discussed the allegations
and developed a plan. FCS will now be present via speaker phone
whenever FCW2 is transporting a youth placed in Foster Parent 1
and Foster Parent 2’s home. This will allow for another person to
be witness to any conversations that occur. FCS will also attend
home visits with FCW2.
FCS reported they did not have any financial concerns about the
foster parents. However, it was noted that DOC rates were an
ongoing issue, as the family typically only took youth with a higher
DOC rate. Youth A was initially placed with a $300 per day rate,
based on his history. However, at the time of the 30-day
reassessment the foster parents reported no behavioral issues
and no difficulty in school. Therefore, the DOC score was lower,
and the rate was decreased. Foster Parents requested a higher
rate, which was denied by central office. Subsequent requests
were made for $200 and $150 per day, but they were also denied,
as the youth did not have significant needs that required
intervention by the caregivers. Youth A was attending therapy, but
the foster parents were not transporting him. Therefore, that could
not be incorporated into the DOC. A few weeks before this
complaint, the foster parents requested a higher rate for another
youth in the home. FCS called to discuss what concerns there
were, as FCS was under the impression the youth’s behavior had
improved. Foster Parent 1 stated the youth’s behavior had not
8

improved. FCS asked Foster Parent 1 to email details about the
behaviors and what they were doing to manage them. Foster
Parent 1 agreed but did not submit anything. FCS reported the
foster parents do a lot of fun activities and family events with the
youth in their home. The kids enjoy being there. However, none of
the activities are relevant to what is required for a higher DOC
level. FCS reported they did not have any concerns about the
home. There were no concerns about the care or safety of the
youth. The foster parents had not been scheduling therapy
consistently or transporting youth. But the caseworkers have
stepped in to make sure appointments occur.
Regarding the trip out of the country, the foster parents told the
youth that they were all going. The youth then told their parents,
who contacted the agency and asked about it. FCS stated the
foster parents were never told “yes” about the trip. When it first
came up, there was discussion about written parental consent and
court approval, and the need for passports. FCW2 worked on
getting consent and travel authorizations. The foster parents
informed FCS that they put a deposit down for two youth as the
parents verbally consented. The foster parents asked if they
should put a deposit for the third youth. FCS said they could, but
the agency was still working on obtaining written approvals.
Through all of this, the youth were calling the agency and urgently
asking for information about plane tickets and communicating with
their parents and the foster parents. There was a lot of go-
between, confusion, and misinformation happening. Section
Manager then had a conversation with Chief Administrator
regarding travel and passports. Ultimately, Chief Administrator did
not approve the trip. FCS and FCW2 spoke with the youth about
the decision. Youth A did not seem upset. Youth B seemed
indifferent. Youth C was upset and did not want to talk about it.
The foster parents were unhappy in the meeting that occurred
regarding the trip. The foster parents reported in the meeting
FCW2 made Youth A uncomfortable, but did not provide any
details. Youth A’s mother also called to report this. Based on the
call with Youth A’s mother, it seemed he was upset about a
conversation FCW2 had with him about independent living. FCW2
reportedly discussed a specific independent living program and
went over the questionnaire with Youth A. Youth A then called his
mother in a panic, stating that he signed paperwork to go to
independent living and felt he was tricked into doing it. FCS
explained to Youth A’s mother that he did not sign anything, it was
only a questionnaire to gather more information about his IL skills.
9

Youth A’s mother was previously in agreement about IL, but
changed her mind after the trip out of the country was not
approved. Youth A later went on a visit to the IL program and
determined he did not want to go there. IL was not pursued any
further. FCS reiterated that she has observed Youth A with FCW2
on several occasions, and Youth A never seemed uncomfortable
with her.
Licensing Worker was interviewed via video call on 3/17/25.
Licensing Worker reported they had not witnessed any comments
made to youth about either foster parent being financially
motivated. However, Licensing Worker acknowledged that staff
were aware the family would not accept a placement if the DOC
rate was less than $250 per day. In addition, if the rate were to
drop, based on previous experience, the foster parents would
likely ask for replacement. This happened a couple of times.
However, these discussions with the foster parents never
occurred in front of youth. Licensing Worker stated that she was
somewhat familiar with the youth in the home. The youth had
behavioral issues. However, they were not enough to qualify for a
level 3 DOC.
Licensing Worker reported there were several special evaluations
regarding the foster parents. Some were with the previous agency
and some after transferring to this agency. None of the special
evaluations involved finances or DOC rates; most were regarding
behavior management.
Licensing Worker reported Foster Parent 1 did tell her they were
concerned about comments made by FCW1 and FCW2. Licensing
Worker stated the team met internally to discuss the concerns. A
meeting was then held virtually with Foster Parent 1, in which they
discussed the concerns and the trip out of the country not being
approved. Foster Parent 1 indicated they felt misled and attacked.
Licensing Worker reported she heard the youth make statements
to the foster parents about the foster care workers, and
statements to foster care workers about the foster parents. Which
seemed to indicate there was some manipulation or triangulation
going on. Possibly because the youth were upset about the trip or
something else. Licensing Worker stated she got the impression
some of the youth were trying to get what they wanted by pitting
the adults against one another. However, she did not have
concrete information to support that theory; it was just their feeling
that tensions had increased since the trip was canceled.
10

Youth A was interviewed face-to-face on 4/9/25. Youth A reported
he was in the foster home for about six months. Youth A stated he
enjoyed the home, and they did a lot of fun activities together.
Youth A stated he disliked the restrictions regarding internet
usage. Youth A reported he thought FCW2 was a good worker
and easy to talk to. However, both foster parents had said they felt
FCW2 lied to them. This was specifically in reference to the trip
that was planned. The foster parents said FCW2 approved the
trip, then said she did not. Youth A reported he was a little
disappointed about not going, but was overall okay with it. Youth
A denied ever hearing FCW2 say anything negative about either
foster parent or ever discuss foster care money. Youth A stated he
never heard any other youth in the home report FCW2 made
negative statements or discussed foster care money. Youth A
stated he never heard FCW1 make any negative comments or
discuss money either. Youth A reported he looked into an IL
program with FCW2, but ultimately decided it was not for him.
Youth A anticipated reunification to occur soon, which made IL
seem unnecessary. Youth A reported he was never uncomfortable
when working with FCW2. Youth A denied hearing FCW1 or
FCW2 state, “What happens in Vegas, stays in Vegas”.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face on 4/9/25. Youth B reported
living in the foster home for about nine months. Youth B stated he
enjoyed all of the activities the family did with the kids in the home.
However, he disliked having some of his personal belongings
taken away, not being able to go outside alone, and losing access
to the internet. Youth B discussed these concerns with FCW2
after the interview.
When asked if there were any concerns about interactions
between FCW1 or FCW2 and the foster parents, Youth B stated
Foster Parent 2 said he hates the case workers and did not need
foster care money. Foster Parent 1 indicated to Youth B that they
did not like the workers either. Youth B shared he felt Foster
Parent 2 yelled at youth too much. Youth B indicated he was
indifferent about the trip with the foster parents being canceled.
Youth B stated he never heard FCW1 or FCW2 make negative
comments about either foster parent, or indicate they were
fostering for money. Youth B never heard FCW1 or FCW2 state,
“What happens in Vegas, stays in Vegas”.
Youth C was interviewed via video call on 4/29/25. Youth C
reported the foster parents were great and there were no
concerns. Youth C reported they had no concerns about FCW2 or
FCW1. When asked if there were any concerns between the
11

foster parents and staff, Youth C stated there was some
disrespect going both ways. When asked for an example, Youth C
did not have one. When asked specifically if FCW1 or FCW2 ever
made comments about fostering for money, Youth C responded
yes. Youth C stated they were in the car with FCW2 once, when
FCW2 was on the phone with FCS and said the foster parents
were doing foster care for the money. Youth C stated they did not
hear FCW2 say that exactly, and they could not remember the
specific wording. Youth C stated they did not believe the foster
parents were in it for the money. Youth C did not recall a time
FCW1 made any statements about foster care money. Youth C
reported Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 discussed that they
felt the agency was not treating them fairly. The foster parents felt
both FCW1 and FCW2 thought they were fostering for the money.
Youth C denied FCW2 sharing any documents about foster care
payments with them. When asked if FCW1 or FCW2 ever told
Youth C or any other youth not to tell their foster parents
something, Youth C answered no. Youth C then said FCW2 did
tell the youth first about the trip not happening, and asked the
youth not to say anything, as FCW2 was going to inform the foster
parents. Youth C reported they were upset about not going. But
the foster parents said they would take them once they turn 18.
Youth C stated they never heard anyone say, “What happens in
Vegas, stays in Vegas.” Youth C reported FCW2 was a good
worker and they felt comfortable talking openly with her about
anything.
Documents Reviewed
• Email dated 3/7/25 from foster parents requesting
clarification for travel denial.
• Email dated 3/7/25 to Licensing Supervisor and Foster
Care Supervisor, reporting concerns related to FCW2.
• Email dated 3/7/25 from foster parents to Licensing
Supervisor, requesting a copy of their licensing file.
• Case records for Youth A, Youth B and Youth C were
reviewed. The following information relevant to the
investigation was found:
• A TDM occurred with Foster Parent 1, Foster Parent
2 and agency staff as reported, to discuss the trip not
being approved.
• Case contacts were located that discussed the
removal request for Youth C and foster parent’s
dissatisfaction with lower DOC rate.
• Youth C was moved from the foster home on 4/16/25
at the request of the foster parents.
12

Analysis No violation was found. There was insufficient information to
determine a violation of licensing rules.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
